page.title: 06GRABBIST HILL
page.content: Grabbist Hill runs from Dunster to Wootton Courtenay. On the steep end of the hill above Dunster, on the south facing side, ledges have been cut in the hillside where the cloth that used to be made, called Dunsters, was put out to dry in the sun. From the top of this hill you can see the whole of Dunster and the surrounding countryside. It was here that it is said the well known hymn, "All Things Bright and Beautiful" was composed. A dip in the hill is said to be the armchair of the Giant of Grabbist. According to legend, he was a very kindly Giant, who amongst other things when waving his hands caused a breeze that dried the villagers' washing.
